Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to support leading United States scientists to participate in the research program on "Growth, Form, and Self-Organization", planned over the period of August 22 - December 20, 2017, at the Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences in Cambridge, UK. The specific aim is to extend the planned activities by supporting and encouraging participation by a larger number of leading American researchers, including 12 junior researchers, who would otherwise not be able to participate. The planned program at the Newton Institute is to mark the centenary of D'Arcy Thompson's influential book, "On Growth and Form" - arguably the first treatise on the physics of living systems - by bringing various contemporary strands of inquiry in the spirit of his work into focus and to look into the future of understanding biology. The program will stimulate new interactions and collaborations between physicists, applied mathematicians, computer scientists, biologists, and other researchers interested in morphology, broadly understood. It will aim to open fruitful lines of inquiry and invite new approaches to address the fundamental issues and features of form and function in living as well as inanimate systems.

The program will provide opportunities for cross-fertilization of ideas within and across disciplines on various aspects of shape dynamics in diverse contexts and at diverse scales. Program participants will foster, and in turn be immersed in, an energetic and informal research atmosphere, conducive to innovative ideas, daring propositions, and potential breakthroughs, and to forming new kinds of fruitful collaborations. The Institute offers an ideal environment for such a "ferment" and actively promotes diversity. The program and the Institute work together to attract and ensure participation of women researchers. Considerable efforts and funds will also be devoted to supporting junior researchers and students, assuring lasting impact. All lectures and seminars will be open to the public, filmed, archived and made freely accessible on the Institute's website. The four planned thematic workshops will provide further opportunities for sharing and developing ideas, which will be disseminated through proceedings, papers, and newly emerged research directions and endeavors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Overview

The program Growth, Form, and Self-Organization was conceived to coincide with the 100th anniversary of Sir D'Arcy Wentworth Thompson's book On Growth and Form. Published in 1917, the book has had a lasting impact bringing mathematical methods to the study of living organisms and opening a new field of research - biophysics.

The program aimed to review the progress made since the Thompson's book and stimulate new interactions and collaborations between applied mathematicians, biologists, and physicists. It was designed to maximize opportunities for cross-fertilization of ideas within and across disciplines.

The structured activities consisted of two seminars per week, four workshops, an outreach day, and a number of smaller events. A follow-on workshop and a roundtable were held later. In total, the program hosted close to 60 participants with visits ranging from one week to four months. The five workshops attracted about 250 attenders, and the total number of talks, seminars, and lectures was near 200.

2. Seminars and lectures

The range of seminar and lecture topics reflected the wide breadth of the program itself: from cell migration to shape and function of the nasal cavity; from oil droplets bouncing on a vibrating surface to swimming of aquatic microorganisms; from aggregation of passive particles to insect flight.

The keynote presentation was the Rothschild Lecture on October 10 by Professor Alain Goriely (Oxford), who gave a beautiful talk titled On Growth and Form and Mathematics: Reading d'Arcy Thompson 100 Years On.

2. Four workshops

Workshop I, on Form and deformation in solid and fluid mechanics brought together a strikingly diverse group of scientists from around the world working on applications of modern theoretical methods in solid and fluid mechanics to problems in nature and bioengineering. There were 64 attenders including 42 speakers.

Workshop II, titled Growth, form and self-organization in living systems, was held at the University of Dundee where Thompson spent half of his career. The focus was on recent advances, challenges, and new directions in research on form in plants and animals. The goal was to highlight new mathematical approaches. There were 51 participants of which 38 speakers.

Workshop III, on Shape Analysis and Computational Anatomy showcased a variety of recent advances in mathematical aspects of shape and some of their implications for studies of brain anatomy. The focus was on open problems relating to growth and shape, particularly for medical image analyses. There were 46 participants with 28 speakers.

The theme of Workshop IV, Form in Art, Toys, and Games was more open with the ambition to begin a community of scientists interested in the physics of art - anchored in dialogues with artists and art historians. The workshop attracted 46 participants and included 23 talks given by scientists. There were also 76 attenders at the outreach event, with 9 lecturers intended for broader audience.

3. Art exhibition

Accompanying the program, and extending its interdisciplinary reach, was an art exhibition Form in Art: Art of Form, November 15 - December 15. On view were 14 artworks by ten acclaimed contemporary painters and sculptors whose work engages science in some manner, either by co-opting physics in the creative process, or by drawing inspiration from nature or physics.

The exhibition was officially launched with a one-day symposium of presentations by the featured artists. Among notable highlights were a demonstration of clay modeling by the sculptor Emma Rodgers, and a multifaceted light-sculpting display by Paul Friedlander.

4. Follow-on workshops

A follow-on Workshop V, titled Mathematics of Form in Active and Inactive Media, was held at the Newton Institute two years after the original program, March 25-29, 2019. This workshop focused on mathematical aspects of growth, shape, and deformation in living and inanimate systems. The aim was to review advances and new developments at the frontier of research.

Another follow-on to the parent program was a roundtable on Opportunities at the Intersection of Mathematics, Science and Art hosted on March 4-6, 2020. It brought together 15 experts - scientists, mathematicians, historians of science, and art-historians - and two visual artists for two days of vigorous, unscripted discussions. The purpose was to explore prospects for interdisciplinary projects, anticipate forms of collaborative science-art initiatives, and consider sources of funding.

5. Concluding Remarks

The program was unusually broad in scope and broke new ground in a number of ways. Arguably, the theme of form in art, toys, and games extended the scope of applied physics and provided a new paradigm for interdisciplinary research. Both the structured activities and the informal, impromptus debates contributed to a fertile, enriching, and invigorating program.

The lasting effects have been in new research links established, new collaborative projects started, and new ideas formulated and shared. Many initiatives had been developed and a number of new collaborative groups formed extending and broadening the impact in physics and well beyond.
